content.description: A surprisingly good little intro to roof cracks and inversions. Sit start on handjams way down in the back of the cave. Climb the crack using good jams and perhaps a bit of OW funk. Top out up the easy layback to the left.If anyone knows the original name, let me know.
content.location: This is the roof crack just to the right of Abstraction and Hurricane

content.description:
"Start in pocket at right of shelf using high feet. Climb straight up using runnel for right hand." 

  -SCC topo, Joe at First Avenue Rocks
content.location: Barn Area H1 in SCC topo

content.description: Hidden among a whole field of pleasant, comfortable boulder problems, this claustrophobic romp was never destined for glory. It is, however, sort of entertaining. This would be good mental training for runout desert chimneying. Use a combo of finger locks, hand jams, and OW technique until the crack widens enough to get inside about 10 ft up. Continue squeezing for another 20 ft with lots of assistance from face holds. Skootch out right towards chock stone when the squeeze narrows. Finish with 10 ft of easy but dirty chimneying.If this has been done before and has a name, let me know.
content.protection: Best to boulder. Once you’re in the squeeze, it’d be hard to fall out
content.location: This climb is located in the back of the big cave left of the Abstraction roof. Look for a wavy finger and Hand crack on the right wall, and a big squeeze chimney above.

content.description:

  -SCC topo, Joe at First Avenue Rocks
content.location: Barn Area L1 in SCC topo

content.description:
LOCATION: On the Barn Area G boulder in the SCC topo. Left of Pebble Beach. 

  Start matched in hueco with a lieback. Right hand to next hueco. Left hand straight up to small sloper pocket.  Right hand out to larger sloper; match it.  Right hand out to side pull. Compress and stand up to top out.   

  Boulder is mossy still. Be mindful of your feet on the top out.

"Start on crimp slots and move to your choice of micro crimps. Make long deadpoint to slopey edge. Topout." 

  -SCC topo, Joe at First Avenue Rocks
content.location: Barn Area N3 in SCC topo

content.description: Start on crimps, move up through chickenhead jugs, move to crimpy-jug rail, longer move to right side pull, and top out. Can feel sketchy because of the rock directly behind and below you.
content.protection: Pad and multiple spotters if nervous.
content.location: Arch in the Barn area. Around the right side of B1 (Barn Area on the SCC Topo). Across from the little dugout fireplace.

content.description:
"Start with wide squeeze on crimps and move to good holds on slab to top out."

content.description:
SDS to the left of the dugout fireplace on good low holds. Move up to two small pockets (should be able to fit two fingers in each, up to crimp rail, out to right jug, then fall forward to pinch good loaf with left hand, then copout.  

  Named for the spider that I was warned of as I almost wrapped my fingers around the jug. Friend thought it was a brown recluse, turned out to be a little daddy-longlegs, and we named him, Phil.
content.location: Just to the left of the dugout fireplace on the backside of the D boulder (SCC topo), just across from Razzle Dazzle and B1 on the Arch Boulder in the Barn area.

content.description:
LOCATION: On the Barn Area G boulder in the SCC topo. Right of Pebble Beach. 

  Start with two low pinches. Move out right to large crimp. Left hand to sloper. Follow the slopers up while adjusting your feet to top out. 

  Still a mossy boulder so be mindful of your feet, especially on the top out.

"Start at base of right facing crack climb up to flat jug and mantel out." 

  -SCC topo, Joe at First Avenue Rocks
content.location: Barn Area J2 in SCC topo

content.description: Start low on good jug slot flake. Move up and right through broken crimp to slopers and stand up. Full pad crimp used to be smaller but incut. Broke 1/25/2020 to reveal wider flatter bigger crimp.
content.location: Mosquito Technique Boulder. Uphill side, near semi circle fireplace cave and narrow arete.
